Title: Makoto Gonokami 五神 真
Content:
Dear Mr. Hassan Jameel,

First of all, please allow me to congratulate you on the 75 years of Abdul Latif Jameel and the philanthropic activities of your family.

This is quite an impressive accomplishment.  I particularly respect Community Jameel’s philanthropy in supporting academia to alleviate world poverty.  I would like to express our deep appreciation of what you have done for us as a member of UTokyo Global Advisory Board.  We are very grateful that you have contributed quite a [great] deal for the University of Tokyo.  I trust that Abdul Latif Jameel will reach to new heights in the coming days.

The University of Tokyo is also working hard to achieve the SDGs [UN Sustainable Development Goals] as much as possible and we like to make our university more inclusive.  We are particularly encouraging innovative research collaboration across different disciplines within and between universities. I am very happy to be able to reassure you that we share the fundamental goals on how universities can contribute more to making our society better and sustainable. I greatly appreciate your generosity and continuous support for us. There will be no doubt that our relationship will continue to thrive.

Last but not the least, I would like to say that 2020 is not just a corporate anniversary, it is an anniversary of an awesome journey led by a group with brave spirit of philanthropy.

I feel honored to be able to celebrate such epochal event of the 75th Anniversary with you. All members of the University of Tokyo wish you a prosperous future to come.  Once again, congratulations!

Yours sincerely,

Makoto Gonokami
President , The University of Tokyo

Title: Masato Ishida 石田 將人
Content:
We, Sumitomo Corporation, would like to sincerely express our congratulations for the 75th year’s anniversary of Abdul Latif Jameel.

Nine years have passed, since Abdul Latif Jameel and Sumitomo Corporation, first met.  At that time, through a lot of discussions we came to the conclusion that we have similar corporate culture and can work as strategic partners respecting each other.

Finally, in 2012, we succeeded in jointly establishing Abdul Latif Jameel-Summit which is an exclusive Komatsu Distributor in Saudi Arabia.

It was my dream to establish a distributor in Saudi Arabia for Komatsu Ltd., the world's best brand of construction & mining equipment, together with such a well reputed company as Abdul Latif Jameel.

Since then, we have been experiencing both difficult and good times.  Although the threat of COVID-19 becomes more serious, let us overcome difficulties together.

We wish for your continued success and prosperity in the future.

Sincerely yours,


Sumitomo Corporation
Masato Ishida

Title: Alec Derkaloustian
Content:
"The job comes with a lot of responsibilities - and sometimes stress - because you're working with a very diverse group of people.

Our projects run from China all the way to Morocco and people, cultures, everything is different, so the way you're dealing with engineers here is different than the way you're dealing with them at the other  side of the world.

Working for this Company gives you that confidence that you are somebody in the Company and you are well taken care of.  I would definitely recommend someone to work for Abdul Latif Jameel.

I think the diversity here is a school, a school really, you learn so much from the people around you you deal with Japanese people different Arab cultures Europeans and I feel much better now after 10 years then I started here.

I feel like I'm an international person now that I could survive in any environment."

Simply, the way he put it to me, I could not say 'no', and Hassan is a very charismatic and astute businessman.

the other thing is when I joined Abdul Latif Jameel Machinery in 2013, I had a five minute orientation with Mr. Mohammed Jameel, and in that five minutes the one thing he told me, very loud and clear, was "Arif, we are coming into a new [industry] segment and however we have a huge [customer service] reputation of the past 75 years; you should not do anything - at all - that would affect this reputation adversely."

And we had to start the Company, so that was a Guiding Principle which which came to me, right from the President's desk."

Content:

Content:

Content:
"The [Jameel-Toyota] Scholarship [at MIT] has definitely helped me come here, like if it were not for the financial support that Community Jameel has offered me I would not have been able to go to college such as MIT.  Thankfully MIT is a 'need-blind' school and which means that they did not consider my financial situation in my admission process.  And, they also like help me find like to find the scholarship program and be enrolled into it, so I can like pursue my dream here and, like, be able to afford college.

Title: Yazan Ba'ara
Content:
"So I think the Abdul Latif Jameel-Toyota Scholarship [at MIT] changed my life in that literal sense, I mean, in in that complete sense because, they're the ones who allowed me to attend an MIT -  allowed me to MIT based on my merit and not because or based on my financial ability to.  So, they changed my life by allowing me to attend this marvelous institution by giving me the support that I needed in order to attend this institution. By helping me along the way in case I needed help with with whatever they're doing especially with Community Jameel that does a lot of work in social entrepreneurship and social enterprise - so, to keep it very short, they changed my life by just allowing me to attend the top university in the world and by giving me support to continue that journey in this university.

It has definitely, I think , broadened my horizon.  Sort of, coming to MIT you don't really get exposure to the different fashions of the community to the different people from different socio-economic standards, which is one of the main reasons that I started doing social entrepreneurship, so they really show you,  Abdul Latif Jameel although, sort of, they helped me with the scholarship, they also helped me open my eyes towards what this world really has, and how I can use my MIT education to benefit those in need because I was so sort of fortunate to attend this institution.  Fortunate to receive the support from them.  And the only rational thing is is to give back to your community, the only thing that you can do is give back to your community.  So they helped me open my eyes towards what the community lacks, what hides behind closed doors, what the community needs you in, and give me support to to allow me to give back to the community."

Title: Rezy Pradipta
Content:
"I work in the, in space-science and space-weather, and it's undoubtedly a very global enterprise. I mean, [a] threat from space doesn't just affect the United States or Canada or or European countries actually affects everybody.  So, naturally, we need a lot of international collaborations I think.  What I really want to do forward is to strengthen this international collaboration and try to bridge the gaps that still exist, where there is gaps in expertise, I mean.  It's it's good for people from wealthy countries to collaborate with with scientists from developing countries but the gap in expertise sometimes gets in the way.

Due to my connection to the Abdul Latif Jameel scholar[ship], actually as this new efforts and initiatives from from Community Jameel sprung up like the J-PAL the [Abdul Latif Jameel] Poverty Action Lab [at MIT], and J-WEL for education, and then J-WAFS for water and food security, actually brings a sense of special connection to those efforts even though I'm not really, I'm not directly involved with them, but you know, it feels like we're in the same boat.  And sometimes it helps me when I get stuck on my work that we're not alone in trying to solve the world's problems."

Title: Daren Ambrose
Content:
"The really impressive things is that Mohammed Jameel, our president, is involved day-to-day.  His level of understanding, expertise, involvement, encouragement - he's such a creative guy.  I mean, the comparison I could draw is a bit like Richard Branson, if you've ever read his books, in the way that he leads, and he doesn't really worry about they say the complication in doing something.  Actually, he can boil it down into really simple compartmentalized things; Mohammed Jameel does that in exactly the same way.

It gives you the empowerment, which I suppose is what we all want. We want that that kind of feeling that we're in control and that we can create something that's quite quite long-lasting and a I suppose, yeah, part of the infrastructure of a ALJ.

The thing you've got going for you is you've got real intelligent people.  I mean, we've got some of the best people here from their backgrounds whether it's finance, purchasing, you know, management.  They're all here.  And it means that, you know, collectively you've got the power in the room to solve a problem.  Or someone's experienced a problem.  So, I think it's really . . .  that's what makes the organization enjoyable, then also I say, yeah, really kind of exciting to work I suppose.

Really the power of ALJ is that it can, kind of, unify its resources and,  give people that empowerment because as a project owner, I'm nowhere near as skilled enough to bring this together, but you've got this power below you that enables it, and it's really, I guess, very rewarding when it all comes together nicely.

Which, doesn't mean it's any easier to do it here, but it does mean we definitely know how to problem solve and deliver on the objective, which I think execution is key to us - and delivering on time is really what it's all about."

Title: John Hasar
Content:
"So, the learnings that I received at MIT, in terms of my engineering education, in terms of the people I met that influenced my life in a fundamental way, either my career or my personal life, will continue.  And the learnings actually will never stop.  And, for example, I did spend, I did use, my engineering education for seven years in [the] oil and gas industry and then I worked on those sort of innovative projects aspects of that, as a MIT nerd, which was found applicable for me!

Then I, now I am translating those learnings into a low-carbon future of the World, transitioning and helping this energy system, such that we will be able to change the course of climate change.  We will be able to help energy security wherever we are and also do that in a cost-efficient way for the consumers.  [So], that they will see a financial reduction in their energy bills.

Content:

Being able to see how Community Jameel has been so generous and successful in some of these initiatives with MIT was really interesting, eye-opening.  You know there's so much talent around the world MIT certainly gets its share of smart people undergrad, graduate, postdocs,  you name it, professors, to here.  And you know when I think about Jameel and where I'm a recipient of their generosity I also think about, you know, a lot of what's possible at MIT, a lot of the great work that gets done here, also not possible without the likes of the Jameel group,  and their generosity right.  And you know, and then again it spurs my thinking and certainly think about wow you know folks who are able, and groups and organizations that's able, that have had the means to contribute, to donate I mean it's special, you know.

It allows this environment to prosper and to thrive so, so I think that's great."

Title: Arantxa Mencía
Content:
"The first memory that came to my mind, it was . . .  I will never, never, forget the day I joined Abdul Latif Jameel, because the same day, my second child was born.  We were signing the agreement with a small company we had in Spain (Stakia for Water).  Abdul Latif Jameel decided to incorporate that company within the group: Almar Water Solutions was created.

We were with the notary signing the agreement at three-thirty in the afternoon . . .   and at five pm, my girl was born!  I rushed from the notary to the hospital!

So, the 'Almar Project', for me, is also like my little kid!  Both of them are three years old; it has been an adventure!  And I'm very happy for that.

It has been a very intense three years, but I have to say the most challenging, and the one I have felt the most positive about being part of this group is the 'Shuqaiq Project.'  It has been a challenge as as Almar we were very new company, Abdul Latif Jameel didn't know us so much, and one day we arrive with a project of US$ 600 million!  An entirely new project of a large desalination plant.  But, we have felt, always, backed by the Company, encouraged.  And although we had some tough times (it hasn't been an easy project) we have always counted on the [Jameel] family and they have been backing us and it has been a pleasure to be part of that."

Title: Mariano Berges
Content:
"Well I think that the first thing that surprised me when Abdul Latif Jameel acquired FRV was the flexibility and the trust that they had in the team, because it is true that usually, in these kind of operations, you usually put some members of your [own] team on the management and this is something that really didn't happen in our case.  And that shows a big trust in the team and that they knew what they were doing.

The second thing I think is also the innovational spirit that is in the group especially on Mr. Jameel.  He can be quite active with WhatsApp, sending messages about a lot of technologies that appear all around the world and it is true because his his he can collect a lot of information with the different people that he meets with and also with a lot of initiatives that they have in different institutions including including MIT, and he sends forward to all of us.  And he can be very intense with WhatsApp and he's quite curious about what is going on, and how those new things can be implemented in the business also and that is very good because that pushes the team."

Title: Javier Huergo
Content:
"A couple of other memories I have, are pretty much related to the Jameel family, actually.  To Mohammed Jameel, to Fady Jameel . . .  I'm quite impressed at how close they are, to the people, to the organization, to the business.  They don't treat you as an employee, but as a human being and that's something you don't expect from a family owned business; you maybe expect the family to be, you know, like, people far away from the day-to-day of the business.  It's totally the opposite.

Mohammed Jameel is a warm man.  He knows about everything that happens in the organization, he knows about the personal problems that everyone has in the organization.  I went through very tough times, a couple of years ago, personal times, with my wife who was sick.  And some of the, you know, when my wife passed away one of the first messages of condolences was from Mohammed Jameel.  So, this makes you feel important.  Makes you feel that you are part of something which is not only an organization but closer to a family.

The experience has been really exciting for all of us.  Has been very positive.  I do believe that we have developed the business, in a sense, that we probably could not have thought about without the support of the Jameel family.  And we feel really proud of what we've done together.

And we hope, of course, to do more in the future, right?"

Title: Carlos Cosín
Content:
"For me was very important to decide . . .   that ALJ has to be by my partner and specifically 'MJ' [Mohammed Jameel] and Fady [Jameel], okay, because I have to create something from scratch at 55, which is it was not easy.  Not an easy moment, okay.  But I met probably hundreds of potential investors, equity founds, and big, big. very well-known equity funds.  But my project needs something with a vision of long term, and that [would] really have confidence in myself and my team. 

I feel then, a very good support for growth from from the family, and also I have to remark that in this phase, which has to be DC, because the market is quite difficult when you have to [start from] scratch with no references, no credentials ,in the jungle of market.  I have to recognize that during these phases we have faced two big problems, that has to be canalized from the human part of our lives and and they respond pretty well.  I don't I don't think that the other partners can respond in this way.  I don't want to mention because it's very personal but I have to say that the human relationship we have and the credibility when we open this transparency behavior with them, they respond.

I'm very proud, I'm very proud to continue.  And I think we have a long life together because the market is there, the team is very happy and I create opportunities.  I have not a personal interest in this I think now Almar is a platform that has to create solutions for the future, of course.  You have return back their investment that you have.  Then I'm very happy for the decisions. That's my personal opinion and I think so [it's] the same for my directors that [are] coming with me for the last 20 years."

Title: Nikolay Pirozhkov
Content:
"I guess the main thing I like about my job, especially it Abdul Latif Jameel, is that this Company has a lot of diversity.  Diversity and cultures, diversity and businesses, geographical locations.  All of this has its own specifics, as you can imagine.  We're present in North Africa all the way to Far East: different regulations, different you can say 'ethics',  this is kind of the main challenge. Trying to understand all of this and put it in line with the corporate objectives of Abdul latif Jameel.

So, it's a very safe, dynamic, environment, which forces you to kind of be at the edge.  I always keep on learning things and trying to improvise, you can say, to to blend together different, we can say, legislation, different mentalities, and to work under one umbrella of ALJ.

That motivates me quite a lot and it's pushing us to be, you know, 'there' - talking to the people, learning their needs and requirements, trying to come up with the solutions.  So in this Company there are opportunities for employees to shine to bring their know-how to the to the table and basically put it in work."

Title: Tadaaki Naito 内藤 忠顕
Content:
Dear Mr. Mohammed Abdul Latif Jameel,

As chairman of the NYK Group, please allow me to offer my utmost congratulations to Abdul Latif Jameel Company Limited. on the 75th anniversary of its founding.


Almost 50 years ago, in 1971 to be exact, NYK began shipping Toyota vehicles and automotive parts from various origins to the ALJ Group mainly in the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia.  Amid stagnation in the early 1990s and a boom in the 2000s, NYK remained committed to delivering vehicles of the highest quality.  Today, the ALJ Group is the No. 1 car distributer in Saudi Arabia, and as a result of the synergy between our two Groups, NYK has grown to become one of the largest car carriers in the Middle East and around the world. At NYK, we have the greatest respect for the historical partnership that we have developed with the ALJ Group over the years.


Since our founding in 1885, the NYK Group has been a part of the development of the world economy and the subsequent improvements in quality of life for people around the globe. We are proud of the role that we have in supporting the lives of so many, and we carry out our responsibilities by creating value for society while meeting its requirements for safety and environmental protection. We are truly grateful for the trust that we have been accorded over the years, and particularly our everlasting partnership with the ALJ Group.


The commercial relationship between the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia and Japan has brought benefits to us all, and we are proud that the ALJ Group and the NYK Group have helped the economies of the two countries thrive, our cultures become closer, and goodwill among our people blossom.


The ALJ Group has my enduring wishes for many more years of prosperity and triumphs.


Very respectfully yours

Tadaaki Naito
Chairman
NYK Group

Title: Akio Toyoda 豊田 章男
Content:
Dear Mr. Mohammed Jameel, Mr. Hassan Jameel

We would like to congratulate each member at Abdul Latif Jameel for your 75 years of dedicated service worldwide.

Ten years after the establishment of ALJ in 1955, the partnership between Toyota and ALJ began when 4 units of Land Cruisers were imported to Saudi Arabia. During that time, when the market was dominated by American and European brands, it was certainly not an easy decision to start a business with an unknown brand like Toyota. The auto business, which started from a small showroom next to a gasoline station and sold only 5 units, has grown to sell over 100,000 units in just 20 years and is now the world’s largest independent Toyota distributor. During our collaborative journey, we have together built a strong relationship based on mutual trust and this successful journey was an outcome of your ceaseless efforts and overcoming uncountable hardships.

We admire all of your tireless work in not only business activities centered on automobile sales and services, but also contribution to the society through Community Jameel in the spirit of SDGs, to earn greater respect, appreciation, and trust from our local customers and society.

We are also extremely proud that ALJ is committed to promoting motorsport through activities such as Dakar Rally, and the 3-year contract as main partner for all Saudi motorsport tournaments. Not only will this garner greater interest in cars among younger generations, but also help to grow the Toyota fan base in Saudi Arabia, as well as contribute to “Vision 2030” through sports activities.

With a common vision for the future to make the world a better place through “mobility for all”, we sincerely wish you all continued success in the next 75 years, as you strive to mass produce happiness in each and every customer you service in your country, town and branch. Last but not least, we wish you and your family prosperity, happiness, and good health. Let’s continue to work together as ONE TEAM, ONE TOYOTA!

Sincerely yours,

Akio Toyoda

President, Member of the Board of Directors
Toyota Motor Corporation

Title: L. Rafael Reif
Content:
"I met Mohammed, maybe for the first time, in the mid ’90s, maybe early ’90s to mid ’90s.

I remember my initial reaction is — very much what stayed with me all these years — is an extremely kind, generous, pleasant person, easy to talk to, very intellectually stimulating.  And the part that I remember the most that has been true to this day, and is the part that I enjoy the most, is his curiosity.  He's incredibly curious about just about everything.  And that each time we have a conversation, not only I enjoy it thoroughly, but it always makes me think.  And there is not a single conversation that doesn't end with me trying to do something, that I know that I’ve got to do something.  And, quite frankly, very often, it makes us both to something together, which is even better.

So, Mohammed would turn to me at a surprising moment to say, “Well, what's your latest idea?  What are you thinking these days?”  And that — that, just about every time — whatever I share with him gets much better in the conversation and becomes an action item for he and I to do something together – it has happened quite a few times in the last few years.

There is so much to admire about Community Jameel.  There are many family foundations, of course, and just about every one of them focuses on a particular topic or domain whether its museums, or the arts, or, or health, or education.  Community Jameel, it feels like its goal is basically to improve the human condition – it’s to do whatever is needed to improve the human condition.  To impact the lives of many people who society has forgotten.

And, and that seems to . . . that's really, what drives Mohammed - and that seems to be what's driving Community Jameel.  And that is, that is something really to recognize and admire - it's very unusual!  I don't know of any other foundation that focuses so much on impacting people. People who need to be touched.  It's always important for them to impact large numbers of people with what they do.  Whether it's with poverty or whether it's water insecurity, you name it - that's a critical component of everything they do.

Community Jameel has been extremely important to MIT.  Community Jameel really cares deeply about improving the human condition, improving what’s, what needs to be fixed in the world.  MIT is very much the same way.

It's really a perfect match.  And they have been to us an amazing force to enable all the things we want to do.  We're addressing poverty; that's important to Mohammed and to Community Jameel.  We're addressing water and food insecurity; that's important to them.  We’re addressing education worldwide, whether it’s in refugee camps; that's important to Community Jameel.  We're addressing the use of technologies like AI in health; that's important to them.  So, the matching goal from objectives is pretty much perfect.  And they have enabled MIT to do all the things that MIT actually wants to do as well.

Mohammed has described to me, years ago, how his father brought him up and educated him.  And the tremendous respect and love that Mohammed has for his dad comes through strongly in those conversations.  And it's very clear that that shaped Mohammed’s view of the world.  And that, and it's very clear, that also has shaped the way he has brought up his own children.

In my humble opinion Community Jameel, the whole Jameel family, is truly a gift to the world."

Title: Bono
Content:
The day I first came into contact with Mohammed Jameel was a blessed one it turned out…

We met through Quincy Jones, and discovered a shared interest in tackling the structural causes of extreme poverty . . .

To try and make better sense of something that doesn't make any sense . . . i.e. how is it the case that we as a human race can put a man on the moon, yet here on earth vast numbers die because of an accident of latitude and longitude?

Their address.

We shared an analysis that these issues were at their heart about injustice, but I was struck by his engineer-like razor focus on finding specific solutions.  He introduced myself and my campaigner colleagues to Esther Duflo at the [Abdul Latif Jameel] Poverty [Action] Lab (J-PAL) at MIT in 2005.

The ONE Campaign believes strongly in 'factivism', and the work of the Poverty Action Lab and Community Jameel's commitment to forensically researching evidence-based interventions has been game changing. 

As we say in Ireland: "he is some man,  for one man."

75 years, countless lives transformed.

Yours with gratitude and respect,

Bono
Co-founder of ONE
Lead Singer, U2

Dear Mr. Jameel, it's my pleasure to be with you, to congratulate you for this 75 years of philanthropy.

Since we met in Monaco, both of our foundations have been able to achieve a lot.  We are working together today in, Mosul in Iraq, to build a laboratory and we are also in Amman in order to establish a bioforce site in Middle East.

It's always been a pleasure to work with you and your people and your staff .  We are very impressed by what you achieve and we are very proud and happy to be with you.

All my best and best wishes for 2021.

Thank you.

Title: Wael Al Awar
Content:
"My name is Wael Al Awar and I'm the Principal Architect and Founding Partner of 'waiwai.'

I had the privilege of several years ago being contacted by Fady Jameel.  He had an amazing idea to realize a mixed-use cultural and arts hub in Jeddah.  At that time, such a project was unheard of in the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia.  It was a very challenging project to have such a mixed-use development, but he really wanted to get a very communal facility to the people of Jeddah and the community, and to support the local arts scene.

As an architect I worked very closely with Fady Jameel to realize this project as well as with Art Jameel,  who are filled with philanthropy and support to the local arts scene in Jeddah and the rest of the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia.

I would like to congratulate Abdul Latif Jameel on their 75th birthday and wish them a thousand more years to come.

The world needs such great companies and such great people that give so much to the world."

 

Learn more about our contributor here.

Title: Ariel Pastrana Mallari
Content:
I am Ariel Pastrana Mallari, I cam from The Philippines. I've been here since 1993, and I am currently working with Abdul Latif Jameel for 27 years.

Working with Abdul Latif Jameel, is an ideal workplace to cultivate and maximize your full potential, that benefits the Company, the community, the society and the customer as well. 

The teaching of Abdul Latif Jameel with The Toyota Way that we value our customer with a high degree of respect plus delivering treatment to the customer for long term benefits and growth of the Company.

Abdul Latif Jameel has given a big impact possibly in my life because I learned so many things working under Abdul Latif Jameel, especially the value of efficiency and effectiveness in doing every task that will lead to the prosperity of all.  And that kind of mindset, I am able to replicate in our country back home.  That will guide the people to be productive.  That will add value to the community and to the society as well.

Title: Dr. Tristram Hunt
Content:
"Hello.  My name is Tristram Hunt. I'm the Director of the Victoria and Albert Museum in South Kensington, in London and I'm here to congratulate the Jameel Family on 75 years of remarkable philanthropy.
 
At the V&A we are honored to host the Jameel Gallery, showcasing art and design from the Islamic Middle East and North Africa.  Situated at the very heart of our museum, this is one of our
most beautiful and most important galleries.
 
The Jameel Family have not only supported the construction of that gallery, crucially, they've supported its intellectual development through endowing curatorial posts - and to my mind that's what always strikes me about the Jameel Family support for art in this country - that they mix historicism and modernity.  They think about the traditions of Islamic art and design and how that can be showcased and developed and challenged today.
 
That's why we're also so privileged to lead on the 'Jameel Prize for Art and Design' inspired by Islamic traditions, which is hosted here at South Kensington but now travels around the world.
 
In the coming years, we are going to build up our really fruitful relationship with Art Jameel, and this seems exactly the kind of cosmopolitan, international, partnership showcasing the very best work from the Middle East, here in London, building up partnerships between people and countries and identities which has been at the heart of the Jameel Family's mission.
 
So we're very grateful to the Jameel Family.
 
We congratulate them on 75 years of generosity, leadership and cultural insight and wish for many more to come."
 
 
Learn more about our contributor here.
Slider Quote: “75 years of generosity, leadership and cultural insight”

Title: Max Hollein
Content:
"Hello.  I'm Max Hollein, Director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York, and I want to congratulate Community Jameel on their 75th birthday.  The Jameel family and Community Jameel have been tremendous supports of The Met and we're happy to collaborate on several initiatives.

Most importantly in recent times the Jameel fund created a special endowment, here at The Met, to foster initiatives in the area of Middle Eastern culture and art: a) acquisitions, b) supporting programing and c) supporting the translation of educational materials of The Met into Arabic.

I have to say that I was privileged to visit the Jameel Art Center in Dubai, most recently just before the pandemic, and I was simply blown away by the ambition of the center; by the excellence of its' programing; the beauty of its' architecture and the important position that it takes in the Middle East as a regional hub for the exchange of art and culture.

And that's also what our relationship - between The Met and the Jameel family - is all about: fostering the exchange; fostering the understanding; fostering the ability to have art flourish, especially art from the Middle East, and we'll continue to do so.

So, we're happy to collaborate and I want to congratulate again Community Jameel [and Art Jameel] for their 75th birthday."

 

Learn more about our contributor here.
Slider Quote: “fostering the exchange; fostering the understanding; fostering the ability to have art flourish”

Title: Aaron Cezar
Content:
My name is Aaron Cezar and I'm the Director of Delfina Foundation, in London.  Delfina Foundation is an arts organization that works globally providing opportunities for artists and thinkers to develop their practice through residencies, exhibitions and events.  For the last three years, Delfina Foundation and Art Jameel have been strategic partners working together to nurture and promote art from, and in relation to, the Middle East.

Whilst our relationship with Art Jameel might seem short, at three years, it feels like we've been working together for much longer.  Perhaps this is because we share mutual aims, and over the last decade, or more, we have been admiring Art Jameel's commitment to art education, to access to the arts and developing individual practitioners, artists and curators.  Now people, ultimately, make up organizations and the conviction and the power of the arts to transform society is one that is strongly held by everyone whom I have had direct contact with, from Mohammad Jameel, to Fady Jameel, Antonia Carver, the Director of Art Jameel as well as the entire team at Community Jameel.  

I think the notion of 'family' defines Abdul Latif Jameel, as well as our work at Delfina Foundation.  And here I'm not talking about bloodlines; I'm talking about how one engages in the world; develops external partnerships, and cares for the wider community as well as the planet.

Delfina Foundation is very thankful for our strategic partnership which has sustained our vital work and we congratulate Abdul Latif Jameel on 75 years of philanthropy.

 

Learn more about our contributor here.
Slider Quote: “the notion of 'family' defines Abdul Latif Jameel . . . how one engages in the world . . . and cares for the wider community”

Title: HE Noura Bint Mohammed Al Kaabi
Content:
Warm greetings!  I want to extend my heartfelt congratulations to Abdul Latif Jameel on its platinum jubilee.

At one level, it is the celebration of a 75 year old vision of exemplary entrepreneurship straddling diverse sectors; at another it is the celebration of a 75 years of a tradition that stands out for its philanthropic commitment and community support.

Art Jameel, Bab Rizq Jameel and Community Jameel are integral parts of a vision that helps us look beyond the material aspects of life.  It was in 2003 that the group has made serious inroads into efforts for social change.

I am happy to have associated with Art Jameel and its multifaceted bouquet of activities aimed at enriching the art scene in the Gulf and beyond.

I believe the contributions of Art Jameel in nurturing the art scene and the region have been spectacular.  It has done more than most, in fostering contemporary art practices and creative entrepreneurships in the Middle East.  It has also provided a vibrant platform for cultural dialogue and exchange across boundaries.

I share your vision and your noble goals.  It has been a delight working together with you for taking our art scene to newer heights of creativity on this momentous occasion when Abdul Latif Jameel completes 75 years of impressive work across sectors, I wish you continuous success and accomplishment for years to come.

I would like to end by reminding everyone of Abdul Latif Jameel's Founder's favorite Arabic proverb, which is so inspiring:  "If a wind blows; ride it!"

 

Learn more about our contributor here.
Summary:
Cabinet Member and Minister of Culture and Youth
United Arab Emirates
Slider Quote: “a vision that helps us look beyond the material aspects of life”

Title: Faisal Abdalla
Content:
"I joined Abdul Latif Jameel, back in 2001, and since then it has been an amazing story!   A wonderful opportunity to see how passion, dedication, the ultimate of  entrepreneurship, all combined together to deliver an amazing operating company that spans around the world.

More importantly as we celebrate the 75th anniversary of this wonderful organization we also celebrate our contribution to community.

I joined ALJ, and I came from a world that's completely different.  A world that really knew nothing about the heart.  A world that focused on really driving numbers, driving results, but at Abdul Latif Jameel, I was able to see how that, is nicely coupled with the passion for people.  The passion for love in the workplace.

I have seen the two displayed so nicely, so beautifully, and frankly speaking I, I learned so much, about how you can really drive business results with a passion for standing with the smallest in the organization anytime they claim that they have a grievance of any kind.  I've learned here that actually, if you really want to drive results, if you really want to get growth, you must look at the hearts of the people.  Because it's the people that delivered the results.

This is a place that has got more passion -  more passion for people, than people can ever imagine."

 

Learn more about our contributor here.
Summary:
Vice President
Abdul Latif Jameel Motors Saudi Arabia

Title: Eng. Faisal Al Samannoudi
Content:
"Working in Abdul Latif Jameel is really an exciting journey, and it's a Company that abides with its values.

Working with my grandfather - in those days I was still young, I was in school - I remember he was in a wheelchair, but he used to consistently, every day, visit [Abdul Latif Jameel Motors Toyota] branches.  Even when he was sick and admitted sometimes to the hospital next day, I would find him in the office.  I would see how humble is he with the tea-boy, with his office manager, and it was weaved into my mind and heart - how humble is this guy?   How great is he, and at the same time how humble is he?  And how kind he is with people.

I'm working on his biography, so I know some of the history and the kindness that he used to do.

He assigned someone to do some legal work and legal case and this guy did it very professionally, and did not cost him much.  If he had lost the case, it would've cost him a lot.  And when he came back, and understood that the case is closed, he went to him and he said: "do you own a home?"   He said "No I don't own a home,  I rent."  so, basically after a few weeks, he took him, and passed by and took him himself, to a small villa.  And he told him "How do you like this villa?" so, he said "it's a beautiful villa";  he says "This villa is yours!"  because he valued the achievement of this guy.  And because he's very, very fair, he gave him this opportunity to have to own his house.  And up to today, this guy lives in his house.

So, basically appreciating people, rewarding people, is one of the main aspects of our grandfather, Sheikh Abdul Latif Jameel."

 

Learn more about our contributor here.
Summary:
Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
Abdul Latif Jameel Enterprises

Title: Clara Barbier Serrano
Content:
I am Clara Barbier Serrano and I started studying at the Royal College of Music, London, classical singing in September last year and I was told there that my scholarship was to be co-funded by the Andrea Bocelli Foundation and Community Jameel -  and that's how I found out about those organizations, which I didn't know before.

Later on, I found out a bit more about what they do and who they are and I even got the chance to sing with Andrea Bocelli last December for a Christmas concert.  I was asked to sing these concerts with Andrea Bocelli one week before the concert, so I really was not prepared, mentally, or about what I was going to sing and I was very nervous at that time I was in Germany for another project and I received an inquiry to have a phone call with Mohammed Jameel and his two sons, in order to wish me good luck for the concert.  And I was very surprised!  I thought okay, you will . . .  it's just calling me for wishing good luck it's really nice, but I didn't know what to expect at all because I had had one letter, I think, a very official one, from RCM, but I had no personal contact with Mohammed Jameel, or anyone in Community Jameel.

I would like to say thank you for your help to me as an artist and student, but also everything you give for the arts.  I think this is crucial and wonderful how involved you are in these things .  And congratulations on 75 years of philanthropy  - and I hope you can enjoy many more, and this Community Jameel keeps doing wonderful things.

 

Learn more about our contributor here.

Title: Asrar Damdam
Content:
"I am Asrar Damdam.  I am the founder and CEO of Uvera.  In Uvera, we introduce a technology that extends the shelf-life of fresh food up to 63%, on average, without any chemicals and within only 30 seconds of processing.

My story with Community Jameel started in March 2020, while attending the MIT Enterprise Forum and the Start Smart Conference, where Uvera was shortlisted within the semi-finalists within the MIT Enterprise Forum Start-up Competition.  And since then, we've been involved in some workshops and activities that were organized by Community Jameel in collaboration with King Abdulla University for Science and Technology (KAUST) and King Abdulla Economic City (KAEC). 

During these two events, the MIT Enterprise Forum and the Start Smart Conference, that was hosted by Community Jameel, we get the opportunity to meet a lot of investors and also to collect feedback from consumers and visitors to the conference and that helped us a lot to have more insight on how to improve our product further.  

Community Jameel is a prime example for corporate excellence, and we wish Community Jameel a happy 75th anniversary and many more years of success."

 

Learn more about our contributor here.

Title: Mohammed Khashoggi
Content:
"I am Mohammed Khashoggi, the Founder and CEO of Ejaro.  Ejaro is the first fully licensed peer-to-peer car sharing platform for Saudi Arabia and the GCC.

Our company is actually the first platform to be integrated also with the governmental platforms.

We were part of MITEF Start-up Competition with Community Jameel Saudi last march of 2020. One of the very beneficial things that we got out of this program was meeting a lot of investors.  Our network obviously, brand exposure, and yeah it was a quite quite a great experience for us, as well as the mentorship side and the expertise that they also brought to us.

I would like to thank Abdul Latif Jameel and Community Jameel Saudi for the great opportunity that we had with them, and a happy 75th anniversary and many more years to come insh'allah."

Learn more about our contributor here.

Title: Mahmoud Awadh
Content:
I remember, in the year 2006, when we had the 'soft-opening' of the Abdul Latif Jameel Academy, the President, Sheikh Mohammed Abdul Latif Jameel, graced us and congratulated everyone's hard work.

He also said [that] we normally have the vision and philosophy of a 'Guest First' culture but we, as your ALJ family, internally consider our associates first also, since you are very important to us.  He even sent one announcement that despite position, don't use "Mr." in addressing anyone, but say "Dear Associate" which shows that everyone is equal in our family.  In this way, the top management support the associates and is dedicated in providing a very good and health working environment.

We are really grateful for having such a great company who treats us like family.

Title: James Kidner
Content:
"I first became involved with the Jameel family when, about 20 years ago, I was working for [HRH] the Prince of Wales as his Deputy Private Secretary, and this was the time of the opening of the new Jameel Gallery of Islamic Art at the Victoria & Albert Museum.

And His Royal Highness was interested in this family, who were doing so many remarkable philanthropic things that very closely chimed with work that he had been doing over many years.

Almost wherever you look in the world there has been extraordinary impact from this family's philanthropic endeavors, whether it's in the Middle East and their work with with creating opportunities for youth and underserved communities.  Whether it's in healthcare; or education.  Whether it's with arts and heritage and the remarkable revival of craft traditions, which I've seen on the ground in places like Jeddah and Cairo.

There's an extraordinary range and breadth of lives touched by the remarkable work that this family has enabled.

When any of the Jameel family are engaged with a challenge or a problem, they're giving it their full attention, and they're also genuinely wanting to go into those difficult fields - not where everyone else is going, where there may be some easy wins - but actually to look in at the real underlying challenges, and to engage with them at a very human level.

And it's a delight to watch the way that organizations respond to that sort of philanthropy; where it is genuinely the love of the people and of the challenge that they all want to remove, rather than simply an interest in the issue."

 

Learn more about our contributor here.
Slider Quote: “wherever you look in the world there has been extraordinary impact from this family's philanthropic endeavors”

Title: Areej Al Hamad
Content:
I'm Areej Al Hamad, the executive manager of Emkan for financing start-ups, working under the umbrella of Al-Ahyaa Centers Association in Jeddah.

I was honored to work at Nafisa Shams and later at Bab Rizq Jameel.  I was attending a training course at Nafisa Shams, which lasted for three days.  Immediately, I felt much intimacy and affiliation to the luxurious place, the professional work team, the administrative officers and the way the place was organized.  I told my colleague that one day I would be working here.

I received a job offer at Nafisa Shams as a marketing and public relations officer, 6 months later, I was promoted to be a marketing and public relations supervisor.  It's common in Abdul Latif Jameel, Nafisa Shams and Bab Rizq Jameel, that the employee who is proved proficient gets promoted at once.  There is an apparent acreer structure and a clear roadmap for employees' promotion.

Happy 75th Anniversary . . .   I wish Community Jameel more achievements, more success and more professionalism.  I thank the administration, my former colleagues and happy anniversary.

Title: Abdul Wahab Tawfik
Content:
I came from Cairo intending to spend only two years with Abdul Latif Jameel.  Now this is the 35th year, and that means a lot.  This is a very emotional moment, when I get a chance to speak about the Founder, Abdul Latif Jameel, Mashallah.  He represents a deeply rooted school with its unique culture and style.  Everyone who interacted with him learned something from him.  Those who had been dealing with him were wary of his intelligence and deep insight, but at the same time they sought his kindness and mercy.  

I learned many things from him, even my own lifestyle and that of my family, changed completely.  And certainly if I left the Company in any case either for retirement or passing away, I will be very certain because Mashallah the third generation is not far from the second, nor the first.  And with this intellectual transformation, Abdul Latif Jameel will remain, not for another 75 years, but 150 years.

 

Learn more about our contributor here.

Managing Director
Corporate Affairs, Abdul Latif Jameel

Title: Rowaid Muslih M Al Sawaf
Content:
"I joined the company as a management trainee.  I saw a great faith in the national staff and a great interest from the Company's leaders.  Alhamdulillah, during my 18 years I went through many phases in terms of development.

Training , empowerment, and best practices for developing the business environment.  There are many stories that we saw in Abdul Latif Jameel, in terms of business, but the most prominent stories are the charitable initiatives that show Abdul Latif Jameel's interest in community and this is an essential thing we are all proud of.

So many congratulations to Abdul Latif  Jameel for its' 75th Anniversary, and wishing it many more years of development, prosperity and growth.

We promise always to be ready to do our best for Abdul Latif Jameel, because Abdul Latif Jameel is not only a company, Abdul Latif Jameel is not only a place to develop and train, Abdul Latif Jameel is my family."

 

Learn more about our contributor here and here.
Summary:
Chief Corporate Officer
Abdul Latif Jameel Enterprises

Title: Badr Khashoggi
Content:
I am Badr Assad Khashoggi from Medina.  I hold a Masters degree from America in Leadership & Management, and majoring in organization. development.

It was a very nice experience.  After I was dismissed from work, I had to start a new experience, so I was looking for a new job.  I did my own consultations and studies until I got the final idea, that Bab Rizq Jameel was a turning point for me.

The advantage of Bab Rizq Jameel is that its' procedures were reasonable, easy and comfortable.  This made it easier for me to communicate directly with them.  Thanks to them, and I wish them prosperity and progress, year after year, and that we all become one group to drive development together.

Congratulations to Community Jameel. It's only25 years to complete one full century!  And happy anniversary t Abdul Latif Jameel and its' group.

Title: Dr Khaled Azzam
Content:
"I met Mr. Mohammed Jameel several times on social occasions, but I think the one moment that transformed our relationship was during the visit of the late King Abdullah to the United Kingdom, and in a particular visit that the King Abdullah came to Clarence House.  He came at the invitation of the [HRH] the Prince of Wales and he came with a delegation of Saudi very important people, some business people and so forth.  And amongst this delegation was Mr. Mohammed Jameel, who I knew of, and I knew casually but i did not know well.

We were asked to give a presentation by His Royal Highness, to His Majesty King Abdullah of the work that the school is doing in the Arab world and then that was the end of it.  The meeting was finished, and then that evening, I got a call from Mr. Mohammed Jameel, saying I was hearing very carefully what you were saying and I'd like to speak to you more about this.  So, I was very pleased and honored that something happened that day, and somebody actually was paying attention and valuing what we were giving and we spoke for a very long time about what we do, how we engage with young people, how we work in the Arab world, how we have a vision to create a sense of community, a sense of identity, a sense of worth, through the work of the school.

A few days later, I heard from him again, saying that he would like to support us with a major program in the Arab world and he very kindly gave us an endowment fund to be able to support this project,  This project's been going on now, for a good, well, for over 15 years and has graduated many students has influenced government policy and has been one of the most successful outreach programs that The Prince's School has done.

My message to Mr. Mohammed Jameel and Fady,  is first of all, one of gratitude and thanks for having the confidence in sharing the vision with us.  We were doing things that not been done in this part of the world before, and I think looking back at that, the gratitude stems from that moment of faith and confidence in letting us do what we wanted to do together.   And over the years providing their support to make it grow and grow and grow, and become a major initiative in the art world."

 

Learn more about our contributor here.
Summary:
Director
The Prince’s School of Traditional Arts

Title: Dr Zaki Aslan
Content:
"The first discussion that I had with the Director of Heritage from Art Jameel, George Richards, we were trying to explore possibilities where we could have some collaboration because we have interests in common, in the field of cultural heritage, especially in this part of the world.

I was very impressed by the work they've done.  Their experience in this area is notable and it's really appreciated here in the region.  I feel  like not many people are doing such a kind of thing.  The impact is quite important because when we talk about cities, for example like Cairo or Jeddah, where they worked to look into the the important, you know, traditions and crafts in these cities; these are actually forms of life of people.  They form their identity and they form their way of living and we are living at times where we are losing such crafts.  For me Art Jameel is a place that is really encouraging artists, but also especially the youth, and that actually attracted my attention.  So, I think all this brings Art Jameel to the fore, and as a leader, in this particular field, in this particular part of the world.

I would like to say congratulations for all the work that you have done in this part of the world for the arts and for culture and for heritage.

Happy anniversary and please continue this fantastic work that you've done, and we look forward to continuing also working with you."
 

Learn more about our contributor here.
Summary:
Regional Representative of ICCROM for the Arab States
Director, ICCROM Sharjah Office, UAE

Title: Christopher C.M. Lee
Content:
Hello, I'm Chris Lee, Principal of Serie Architects and the  Arthur Rotch Design Critic at the Harvard University Graduate School of Design,  and the architect of the Jameel Art Center in Dubai.

When we first participated in the competition to design the Art Center, I was really struck by the ambition and vision of Fady Jameel he told us that the center must first contribute to the community and harness the power of art to transform their lives and nurture the next generation of artists.

In a way this departs from the conventional order of privileging art over everything else in the design of building its nature.  So, we responded with an architecture that is open, welcoming and calm, made up of a series of courtyards and desert islands.  This, in many ways, is an anthem to the exuberant architecture that you find in Dubai and we're delighted to know that after two years of the Center's opening, it has truly become the house of culture of Dubai.  We continue to receive messages of appreciation and compliments from everyone who has visited the Center.

And I really think that the Center is a true transformative gift that Fady and Art Jameel have given to the community and to the larger art world. And i wish them every success and blessings for many years to come.

 

Learn more about our contributor here.
Summary:
Principal, Serie Architects
Arthur Rotch Design Critic at the Harvard University Graduate School of Design

Title: HM Queen Rania Al Abdullah
Content:
Dear Mr. Chairman,

Please allow me to extend my heartfelt congratulations on the 75th anniversary of the establishment of Abdul Latif Jameel.

Over the past three-quarters of a century of operation, your family's business has not only grown and thrived, but also taken on new dimensions, establishing a rich and inspiring tradition of global philanthropy.

Milestones provide us with unique opportunities to reflect on an organization's legacy.  As someone who has had the opportunity to meet and exchange ideas with both you and your son Hassan, it is clear to me that the passion for improving lives has been a constant in the Jameel family for generations.

Over the past few years, it has been a pleasure to learn more about Community Jameel's important philanthropic work in the fields of education, healthcare, and refugee rights and wellbeing.  Your organization's efforts are a clear sign of your unwavering commitment to meet global challenges with innovation, optimism, and compassion, relying on knowledge-based solutions to uplift communities.

May your many successes continue to pave the way for a long future of excellence and altruism.

Sincerely

Rania Al Abdullah

 

 

Learn more about our contributor here.
Summary: Queen of the Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan
Slider Quote: “the passion for improving lives has been a constant in the Jameel family for generations”

Title: Abdulrahman Gazzaz & Turki Gazzaz
Content:
I mean I think, that when you talk about Art Jameel's impact on the artistic community, the cultural community, and also architects, film-makers and other players in the creative fields, I think that Art Jameel really positions itself as one of the leading institutions where critical thoughts, very well put together exhibitions and very leading programs really have, over the years, proven that, Art Jameel is a leading institution in the field and the region.

It's had a massive effect behind the scenes here in Saudi, but now that Hayy: Creative Hub is opening, I feel that there is a thirst for these spaces.  Hay: Creative Hub is a conversation that everyone here in Jeddah has been having, maybe, for 10-15 years now.  I mean, it's always 'we need creative spaces'; 'we need a space that really brings people together'.

For us, that's one of the main reasons we became architects; because we wanted to question this fragmentation of institutions that we have, and it's extremely interesting that Hayy would bring everything together into one cohesive unit.  And that's what we're hopeful for in the future - that the existence of all these different creatives, or students, or lecturers in one single space occupying the space will definitely generate projects, conversations, a more intellectual train of thought amongst the people that are in that space, and hope to create a ripple effect for more and more spaces like that around the region.

It's really refreshing to see an institution with such a high level of organization and a high degree of  professionalism, especially in the region.  So, its refreshing and we're really excited to see how it's going to develop further once Hayy is open.

Congratulations to the Jameel Family for having 75 years of amazing achievements.  Thank you for always giving back to the community, and thank you for really engaging, not only superficially, but really working hard to understand the community's needs and responding to that.  That is key for any successful philanthropic work and I think it's something that you should be proud of as a corporation as well.

 

Learn more about our contributor here.

Title: Michael Likierman
Content:
"Eileen Gray decided that she wanted to build a house of her own. in 1925.  She was a successful designer, but she designed interiors and all of a sudden she felt that she actually wanted to build a house and she heard of a site that was available here just down the path from the station.  It was really remote its only access was the small path that was called the 'smuggler's path' that leads around the coast so she built her a modern concrete house - the new material being concrete - she built that using extraordinary traditional methods of access.  There were no lorries to get there, they couldn't do anything except bring everything by hand.  So, its importance as a symbol of early 20th Century architecture is enormous.

Any architectural student, worth his salt dreams, of going at least once.  And Mohammed Jameel was extraordinarily enthusiastic at the idea of trying to set-up something that would give a structure for these visits and where they can have facilities for their research as well as having an extremely easy access so that they can see observe and feel the quality of the places.

Having finished the restoration of e1027 we thought it was really worth doing a book to chart it.  Mohammed Jameel thought that was an excellent idea and has decided to help us with the book and is helping us to produce it.

You know when you talk about institutions and anniversaries, it's sort of inevitably you find connections and it just seemed so appropriate when we were able to put together the 90th anniversary of e1027 and the 75th anniversary of the Jameel Family Philanthropy and those two together will make this project, which I hope will be interesting architects all over the world for the next 75 or 90 years."

 

Learn more about our contributor here.

Title: Kenichi Teramoto 寺本 健一
Content:
Dear Mr. Fady Jameel,

I would like to express my sincere congratulations for the 75th year's anniversary of Abdul Latif Jameel.

We have been given the meaningful opportunity to work as architects for several years together with Art Jameel and we are honored to work towards the realization of the Jameel Arts Centre in Dubai, and Hayy Jameel in Jeddah.

From the beginning of he project, I have particularly admired Art Jameel's clear vision in making art accessible to everybody.  Following such a philanthropic vision, the project is realized as a place literally open to the public.  Art Jameel openly supports people connecting to arts, arts connecting people to the world, thus people connecting to the world.

I believe this occasion of Abdul Latif Jameel's 75th anniversary is not only a celebration of the success of the business, but also a celebration of 75 years philanthropic contribution to the region and its history.

I wish Abdul Latif Jameel many more years of accomplishment, opportunity and prosperity.

Sincerely yours

Kenichi Teramoto
Founding Partner, waiwai

Title: HRH The Prince of Wales
Content:
Ladies and Gentleman, it gives me the greatest possible pleasure to be able to offer my warmest congratulations to Community Jameel on achieving their remarkable 75 years of philanthropy.  Needless to say, that I am only so sorry that I am unable to celebrate with you all in person.  Mohammed Jameel, and his family, have been tremendous supporters of my Foundation and my School of Traditional Arts, for a great many years.

I first came into contact with Mohammed when he was supporting the refurbishment of the magnificent Islamic Art Galleries at the Victoria & Albert Museum.  I recall, I opened the Galleries in 2006, the same year that Mohammed kindly agreed to become a trustee of the School of Traditional Arts.  Mohammed has tirelessly served in that role ever since and additionally has served as an extraordinary ambassador for the whole of my Foundation's work, encouraging all those he meets along the way.  

Community Jameel, Art Jameel and my School of Traditional Arts share an ethos, and an artistic outlook, where we together encourage an awareness of the holistic nature of the traditional artist, whose inspiration derives from the higher sources.  And whose skill and dedication creates masterpieces which we can all recognize as part of our world heritage.  I'm delighted therefore, that we have formed partnerships that reach far beyond their origins in London.  Since 2008, my School and Art Jameel have collaborated in Fustat in Egypt, and in 2015, we started our fruitful partnership in Jeddah.

Now, as we look to the future, we are making plans to work together at my Foundation's headquarters at Dumfries House, a place that is of the greatest importance to our work and to our future success.

So, ladies and gentleman, if I may, I would like to renew my special gratitude to Community Jameel for their support over many years and to extend my warmest congratulations on the occasion of this splendid anniversary.

Title: Andrea Bocelli & Veronica Berti Bocelli
Content:
Veronica Berti Bocelli:

We are Andrea Bocelli and Veronica Berti Bocelli, Founder and Vice-President of the Andrea Bocelli Foundation (ABF). It is a pleasure for us to join in on the celebrations for the 75th anniversary of Abdul Latif Jameel.

Before we were philanthropists, we had the honor of being friends with Mohammed Jameel and his vision unquestionably inspired and encouraged us to found our own foundation: in our desire
to optimize and direct our projects in the best way possible.

Since 2011, when we established ABF, he has been part of our Advisory Board and together we have partnered on several initiatives over the last 10 years.

We have founded multidisciplinary research at MIT in order to develop a system of intelligent perception with a wearable high-resolution tactile display aimed at increasing the independence
of blind people. We have also engaged in fruitful dialogue with the J-PAL and J-WEL organizations in our desire to measure the impact of our projects, as well as to offer an innovative educational
approach.

As music was the element that brought us to together in 2019, we have also created a scholarship at the Royal College of Music in London with the Community Jameel to benefit the most talented
and disadvantaged students.

We feel grateful for all we have achieved together but moreover we feel grateful for the esteem, trust and good values we have had the privilege of sharing over our time together.

We hope we will have the opportunity to do so in the near future to empower people and communities all over the world.

Andrea Bocelli:

Dearest Mohammed Jameel, I remember with pleasure the days in which we met, the extraordinary places in which we were able to talk, and the way in which you inspired me to create the Andrea Bocelli Foundation.

I think that I can say that it is thanks to you that today many children in Haiti have a school that they can use.

It is also thanks to you that in Italy, in the places hit by the earthquake, many children have a school and have rediscovered hope.

Therefore, congratulations for this anniversary and a special thanks from me.

I hope to see you again soon.

Title: Professor Alice P. Gast FREng
Content:
"I've known Mohammad Jameel since the early 2000s, when I was at MIT and he served on the corporation.  I was always impressed by his warm personality and his vision as he was supporting the [Abdul Latif Jameel] Poverty Action Lab at MIT.
 
It was wonderful to get back in touch with Mohammad as he came to visit us at Imperial College London.  We share a lot of common goals with Community Jameel, so it was a natural partnership.   As Mohammad came to visit us and we got talking about all the needs that the world had in human health, in poverty, in helping people around the entire world. 
 
I've enjoyed getting to know Fady and Hassan as well as we forged the goals for a Community Jameel/Imperial College London partnership to produce the Jameel Institute together.
 
Imperial College and Community Jameel - through the Jameel Institute for Disease and Emergency Analytics (J-IDEA) are creating practical and effective ways to improve global health and well-being.  We're very much recognizing the importance of applying all that we know about world health to chronic diseases and other health care problems around the world, especially the areas where health and poverty intersect.
 
I congratulate you on the 75th anniversary of Abdul Latif Jameel and your family's philanthropy which is making such a difference to so many people in so many parts of the world.  We at Imperial College London are very proud to be part of this relationship, and we're very proud to be serving that mission for you going forward.   I know that your father and grandfather would be very proud of all of us today congratulations!"

Title: Esther Duflo & Abhijit Banerjee
Content:
Abhijit Banerjee:
It's been our privilege to be associated with Abdul Latif Jameel [Community Jameel] for well nigh twenty years since the day Mohammed, like a comet, appeared in our lives.  And what a twenty years it has been, watching Abdul Latif Jameel transforms everything it touches: old institutions get better, new ones are created, so much innovation.  Touching so many dimensions of human life.  From climate changing development thinking, to making the arts more open to new talent.  It's been exhilarating.

Thank you very much.  Happy 75th!

Esther Duflo:
It's almost a tautology to say that without Abdul Latif Jameel, there would be no J-PAL!  In fact I once referred to Mohammed in his presence as the "J" of J-PAL, and he's become very fond of this expression, using it with his nice smile whenever we had an occasion.  But it goes much farther than that: I think without Abdul Latif Jameel [Community Jameel] and Mohammed Jameel in particular, there would, no Poverty Action Lab in the way it is now.  And it is way beyond the funding.  Of course the funding played a critical role in the beginning - allowing us the freedom to do what we wanted to do and the capacity to do it.  The funding was also there at several critical stages in our development when it was appropriate for us to take it to the next level.

But much beyond the funding, there was all the advice, all the conversations, all the wisdom, that we got from Mohammed Jameel from the very beginning.  This same wisdom that we see in all of the work that Abdul Latif Jameel has done for the past 75 years.  From the very beginning, from his very first conversation, we were asked "What is your ambition?" and from this very simple question, we were asked to define our ambition.  And it's been with us since the beginning . . .  we have enjoyed this friendship. We have immensely benefitted from the wisdom and the advice, and we look forward to 75 more years - at least -  of a continuous relationship.

Thank you Mohammed!  Thank you Abdul Latif Jameel [Community Jameel]l and good luck for the next 75 years!
Summary:
Co-Founders/Directors, Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab at MIT
Nobel Laureates, Economic Sciences 2019
Slider Quote: "Abdul Latif Jameel transforms everything it touches... so many dimensions of human life."

Title: Kevin Watkins
Content:
From all of us at Save the Children all of our friends in Community Jameel,  I want to wish you a very happy 75th anniversary,  and to thank you for the extraordinary work that you're doing in so many countries around the world.

When I think of Community Jameel, there are really three hallmarks to your approach that stand out.   The first is your level of ambition in tackling some of the great challenges of our day: the eradication of poverty; the extension of educational opportunity; the fight against the major killer diseases that still afflict so many communities and countries around the world.  Secondly, it's your commitment to evidence and data in the service of the world's poorest people.  Thirdly, it's your commitment to partnership to listening to communities; to learning from communities to understand the problems that they are trying so hard to solve and being there in support and solidarity with them.

We've been deeply honored to work with you and Save the Children on refugee education support for teachers in the Middle East in particular.  And we're looking forward to working with you over the years ahead on our joint program in tackling climate risk in the Horn of Africa.

So, from all of us, a big thank you for everything that you've done and to say again that we're deeply privileged to be working with you and looking forward to engagement over the years ahead.

Content:

Title: Bacem Anas Romdhani
Content:
My name is Bacem Anas Romdhani.  I'm originally from Tunisia.  My very first 'international launch', in terms of career, happened back in 2006, when I was chosen, through a very rigorous competition, by the World Philharmonic Orchestra in Paris.  And they chose me as one of the five Children of the World.  Through that I went to the Yehudi Menuhin School in the UK in 2014; I joined the Guildhall School of Music and Drama, and I got my bachelor with honors.  And then I joined the Royal College of Music I did my master's degree and I'm currently finishing my International Artists Diploma.
 
When COVID came upon us, my Head of Strings made it possible to find some extra funding to be able to finish my International Artists Diploma degree and I found out that a Community Jameel hardship fund was was in place and, you know, I was really excited that I could be able, I would be able, to finish my my studies.   And it was quite a privilege to know that I am the first Tunisian Arab student to benefit from this hardship fund.
 
Community Jameel is playing a big vital role in the arts and we at the Royal College of Music are very lucky to have their support.  Many international students like myself, overseas students ,our fees for the year is very high and without any financial help it would not be possible to travel abroad to carry on pursuing our career, our dreams of becoming future international artists.  And here is where Community Jameel helps their future support will play a very very big important role, so we are very thankful for that.
 
I would like to congratulate Community Jameel on their 75th Anniversary, I think their philanthropic work for the arts, and elsewhere, is very vital and important for many many people.  Here is to 75 more more successful years.
 
Congratulations!

Title: Tony Blair
Content:
So, what an historic and incredible 75 years it's been for Abdul Latif Jameel and Community Jameel!

Now, I first came across Mohammed, Hassan, Fady and the wider Community Jameel, just after leaving office in 2007, and I was immediately struck by the sincerity of their devotion to the cause of doing good in the world, and also the extraordinary ingenuity they bring to that cause.

And over the years, I've become a huge fan, not just of the work of J-PAL, but of the work of the broader Community Jameel: in health, in education, in climate, and in evidence-based policy making.

They have been pioneers, right at the forefront of innovation from the beginning.  And the incredible thing about this 75 years, is that for every one of those years, and going down through the family and generations, they've always been, at the cutting edge of the future.  They've been people who've understood how the future works, and are prepared to bring the best ideas and the best in innovation to make it work successfully for as broad a number of people as possible.

So it's been 75 years of incredible achievement!  I know it's going to be 75 and more years in the future to come.

A big congratulations to you Mohammed, as my good friend, but to everyone involved in Community Jameel for the incredible work that you do.  We're all very, very, proud of you.  Thank you.

Title: Dr. Mamdouh Sakr
Content:
"I am Dr. Mamdouh Sakr, the manager of the Jameel House of Traditional Arts, Cairo.  My relationship with Art Jameel is a long one, it started in 2008, as I was a member of the team from The Princes School of Traditional Arts working on creating and establishing the educational and training program in Cairo.

Our program offers courses in geometric patterns, flow and patterns observation drawing, in addition to courses in traditional crafts such as gypsum and glass work, woodwork and ceramics,  In addition to the courses we engage our students with the monuments of Cairo and each year we select one of the monuments and our students make replicas of the decorative elements in that monument.

Our program aims to reintroduce the traditional arts and crafts of Egypt and the region.   And also, to raise awareness that these traditions are still living. Title: David M. Rubenstein
Content:
Over the past 25 years, I've spent a lot of time in The Kingdom of Saudi Arabia meeting with investors and other people who've been business partners with my firm and among the most impressive people that I've met is Mohammed Jameel.

Mohammed Jameel is an extraordinary individual who taught me the value of learning how to get along with people who you might disagree with; the value of philanthropy; the value of giving back.  And he's and extraordinary business person as well, but actually I have to say, I don't really admire him so much, because he makes me look bad!

He's a much better businessman than I am, a much better philanthropist than I am, much more handsome than I am, a much better father than I am, a much better mentor than I am - and I just have to say to Mohammed Jameel:  stop making me look bad!  You're doing everything so well!  Try not to do things so well, so I can look a little bit better!

But one of the great stories Mohammed  Jameel told me was that is father was a very preceptive businessperson.   Here's what he did:  An ad., was run in a newspaper in Saudi Arabia asking for a distributor to a little company called 'Toyota'.  And the only person who responded favorably to it was Mohammed's father, Abdul Latif Jameel, and he said, yes, he would be the distributor.  Now at that time no-one had really heard of Toyota.  It was close to the end of World War II, I think the early 1950s, and therefore, people weren't interested!  But Abdul Latif Jameel had the insight to say 'this company might go somewhere, I'll be the distributor'  and that was the launching of a gigantic business empire that Mohammed Jameel has done a terrific job of expanding and enhancing.

But what I admire most about Mohammed, honestly, is his philanthropy.  His concern with people; his concern with giving back to society, that indeed, the whole Jameel family - Mohammed's sons are extraordinary as well.

So, I just want to say: Congratulations on raising terrific children, Mohammed.  Congratulations on being a terrific son to a great father, and congratulations for what you've done in our country, my country, because your philanthropy at MIT and other places is really extraordinary.  So, while I kid about the fact that you make me look bad - and you do - I certainly do admire you.

Congratulations on all that you've done.

Congratulations for having an extraordinary family that makes everyone who knows you proud to say, 'yes, the Jameel family, they're a family I know well and I'm proud to call them my friends'.
Slider Quote: "Mohammed Jameel, an extraordinary individual, taught me the the value of philanthropy; the value of giving back"

Title: Ali Mohammed Qaiem

If I quit the company . . .  I would never work anywhere else in the domains of companies or cars.  Why?  Because I consider this company to be one of the best in the Kingdom.

I wish them a prosperous future, more ambition and all the best.  I hope that they would keep up with his vision and always proceed towards what is better.

Of course, I hope those 75 years would be 100 and more.
